summary: This is an FBI communication from May 2010 requesting copies of California driver's licenses for two individuals whose names were found in an address book possessed by Alfredo Rodriguez. The document details the obstruction of justice case against Rodriguez, who was Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager, and his attempt to sell an address book believed to contain names of underage victims from multiple jurisdictions.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein; subject of obstruction of justice investigation
persons.context: Rodriguez was employed by Epstein in 2005 and came into possession of an address book with names and phone numbers believed to be of underage girls. He failed to turn it over to law enforcement and attempted to sell it in November 2009.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Accused sex trafficker; former subject of child prostitution investigation
persons.context: Epstein was investigated for bringing underage girls to his Palm Beach home for massages and sexual acts. He entered a non-prosecution agreement and pled guilty to lesser offenses in Florida state court.

connections.description: Rodriguez was employed as a house manager and butler for Epstein in 2005.
Rodriguez possessed an address book with potential victim information from Epstein's activities and attempted to sell it, obstructing the investigation into Epstein.

events.title: Start of Epstein Child Prostitution Investigation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein became the subject of a child prostitution investigation.

events.title: Rodriguez Employment with Epstein Ends
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez's employment with Jeffrey Epstein ended, and he retained an address book with names and phone numbers believed to be of underage girls.

events.title: Obstruction of Justice Case Opened Against Rodriguez
events.description: The Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Rodriguez Attempts to Sell Address Book
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez attempted to sell the address book to an undercover employee (UCE) posing as an employee of a plaintiff's attorney suing Epstein.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager, possessed an address book with names and phone numbers believed to be of underage girls and attempted to sell it in 2009.

The address book contained a section labeled 'California Massage' with names of individuals residing in the San Diego and Los Angeles areas, suggesting potential victims from other jurisdictions beyond Florida.

Epstein's non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office was limited to victims identified in the Southern District of Florida, making evidence of victims in other jurisdictions significant.
The FBI was actively seeking driver's license information for two specific individuals named in the address book as part of their investigation in May 2010.
